official-title.#text:
To establish the San Gabriel National Recreation Area as a unit of the National Park System in the
			 State of California, and for other purposes.

Sec. 8. San Gabriel National Recreation Area Partnership.

text.#text: The term

header.#text: Establishment of San Gabriel National Recreation Area

text.#text: The purposes of this Act are—

to provide environmentally responsible, well-managed recreational opportunities within the
			 recreation area, and improve access to and from the recreation area;

to facilitate the cooperative management of the lands and resources within the recreation area, in
			 collaboration with the State and political subdivisions of the State,
			 historical, business, cultural, civic, recreational, tourism and other
			 nongovernmental organizations, and the public; and

to allow the continued use of the recreation area by all persons, entities, and local government
			 agencies in activities relating to integrated water management, flood
			 protection, water conservation, water quality, water rights, water supply,
			 groundwater recharge and monitoring, wastewater treatment, public roads
			 and bridges, and utilities within or adjacent to the recreation area.

Subject to valid existing rights, there is hereby designated the San Gabriel National Recreation
			 Area in the State, which shall consist of approximately 615,245 acres of
			 Federal lands and interests in land in the State as depicted on the map
			 titled

As soon as practicable after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall file a map
			 and a legal description of the recreation area with—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives

			 not, of itself, preclude the activities or land uses up to the boundary of
			 the recreation area.

text.#text:
Not later than 3 years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretaries and the
			 advisory council shall create a comprehensive management plan for the
			 recreation area that fulfills the purposes described in

In developing the management plan required by this section, and to the extent consistent with this
			 section, the Secretaries may incorporate any provision from a land and
			 resource management plan, or any other plan applicable to the recreation
			 area.

The Secretaries shall, to the maximum extent practicable, incorporate the visitor services plan and
			 access study required by section 9 into the management plan required by
			 this subsection.

header.#text: Water rights; water resource facilities; public roads; utility facilities

text.#text: Nothing in this Act—

shall affect the use or allocation, in existence on the date of the enactment of this Act, of any
			 water, water right, or interest in water (including potable, recycled,
			 reclaimed, waste, imported, exported, banked, stored water, surface water,
			 groundwater, and public trust interests);

authorizes or imposes any new reserved Federal water rights or expands water usage pursuant to any
			 existing Federal reserved riparian or appropriative rights;

shall be considered to be a relinquishment or reduction of any water rights (including potable,
			 recycled, reclaimed, waste, imported, exported, banked, stored water,
			 surface water and groundwater) held, reserved or appropriated by any
			 public entity, or other person or entities, on or before the date of the
			 enactment of this Act;

shall be construed to, or shall interfere or conflict with the exercise of the powers or duties of
			 any watermaster, public agency, or other body or entity responsible for
			 groundwater or surface water management or groundwater replenishment as
			 designated or established pursuant to any adjudication, or Federal or
			 State statute including, without limitation, the management of the San
			 Gabriel River watershed and basin, to provide water supply and other
			 environmental benefits as described in—

the Southwestern Willow Flycatcher Management Plan San Gabriel River—Morris Reservoir to Santa Fe
			 Dam dated September 2012; or
the Long-Term Management Plan: West Fork San Gabriel River dated May 8, 1989;

shall be construed to, or shall interfere or conflict with any provision of any judgment or court
			 order issued, or rule or regulation adopted, pursuant to any adjudication
			 affecting water, water rights or water management in the San Gabriel River
			 or Lytle Creek watersheds and basins;

shall be construed to impede or adversely impact any previously adopted Los Angeles County Drainage
			 Area project, as described in the report of the Chief of Engineers dated
			 June 30, 1992, including any supplement or addendum to that report, or any
			 maintenance agreement to operate the project;

shall interfere or conflict with any action by a watermaster or public agency that is authorized
			 pursuant to Federal or State statute, water right or adjudication,
			 including, but not limited to, actions relating to water conservation,
			 water quality, surface water diversion or impoundment, groundwater
			 recharge, water treatment, conservation or storage of water, pollution,
			 waste discharge, the pumping of groundwater; the spreading, injection,
			 pumping, storage, or the use of water from local sources, storm water
			 flows, and runoff, or from imported or recycled water, that is undertaken
			 in connection with the management or regulation of the San Gabriel River
			 or Lytle Creek watersheds and groundwater basins;

shall interfere with, obstruct, hinder, or delay the exercise of, or access to, any water right by
			 the owner of a public water system, or other person or entity, including,
			 but not limited to, the construction, operation, maintenance, replacement,
			 repair, location, or relocation of any well; pipeline; or water pumping,
			 treatment, diversion, impoundment, or storage facility; or other facility
			 or property necessary or useful to access any water right or operate any
			 public water system;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: under, or the application of provisions of, the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
United States Fish and Wildlife
			 Service

text.#text: As used in this section,

header.#text: No effect on existing water resource facilities

text.#text: Nothing in this Act shall affect—

the use, operation, maintenance, repair, construction, reconfiguration, expansion, or replacement
			 of a water resource facility within or adjacent to the recreation area; or
access to a water resource facility within or adjacent to the recreation area.

Nothing in this Act shall preclude the establishment of new water resource facilities (including
			 instream sites, routes, and areas) within the recreation area if such
			 facilities are necessary to preserve or enhance the health, safety, water
			 supply, or utility services to residents of Los Angeles or San Bernardino
			 Counties.

header.#text: No effect on new water resource facilities

text.#text: Nothing in this Act shall be construed to—

impose new restrictions or requirements on flood protection, water conservation, water supply,
			 groundwater recharge, water transfers, or water quality operations; or

increase the liability of agencies carrying out flood protection, water conservation, water supply,
			 groundwater recharge, water transfers, or water quality operations.

Nothing in this Act shall authorize or require the use of water in or the diversion of water to the
			 recreation area or the park lands.
Nothing in this Act shall—

header.#text: Utility facilities and rights of way

text.#text:
affect the use, operation, maintenance, repair, construction, reconfiguration, expansion,
			 inspection, renewal, reconstruction, alteration, addition, relocation,
			 improvement, removal, or replacement of utility facilities or appurtenant
			 rights of way within or adjacent to the recreation area;
affect access to utility facilities or rights of way within or adjacent to the recreation area; or

preclude the establishment of new utility facilities or rights of way (including instream sites,
			 routes, and areas) within the recreation area if such facilities are
			 necessary for public health and safety, electricity supply, or other
			 utility services.
In this subsection:
open to vehicular use by the public; or

used by public agencies or utilities for the operation, maintenance, repair, construction, and
			 rehabilitation of infrastructure, utility facility, or right-of-way.

term.#tail:
means any paved road or bridge (including any appurtenant structures and rights of way) that is
			 operated or maintained by a non-Federal entity and is—

open to the public; or

used by public agencies or contractors for the operation, maintenance, repair, construction, and

header.#text: No effect on public roads or public transit

text.#text: Nothing in this Act—

to take any action that would affect the

creates any new liability, or increases any existing liability, of any owner of operator of public

header.#text: San Gabriel National Recreation Area Public Advisory Council

quote.#text: San Gabriel National Recreation Area Public Advisory Council

text.#text:
Not more than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretaries shall establish
			 a public advisory council, to be known as the
The public advisory council shall—
advise the Secretaries on the development and implementation of the management plan; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: San Gabriel National Recreation Area Act/s:3

text.#text:
advise the Secretary on the development and implementation of the visitor services plan and access
			 study required by
The public advisory council shall be subject to—
the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Advisory Committee Act
usc-appendix/5

text.#text: all other applicable law (including regulations).
The public advisory council shall include 21 members.

After considering the recommendations of the partnership, the Secretaries shall appoint members of
			 the public advisory council to represent the following interests—
two members to represent local, regional, or national environmental organizations;

two members to represent the interests of outdoor recreation, including off-highway vehicle
			 recreation, within the recreation area;

two members to represent the interests of community-based organizations whose mission includes
			 expanding access to the outdoors;
two members to represent business interests;
one member to represent Native American tribes within or adjacent to the recreation area;
one member to represent the interests of homeowners’ associations within the recreation area;
one member to represent energy and mineral development interests;

one member to represent owners of Federal grazing permits, or other land use permits within the
			 recreation area;
one member to represent archaeological and historical interests;
one member to represent the interests of environmental educators;
one member to represent cultural history interests;
one member to represent environmental justice interests;
one member to represent electrical utility interests; and
two members to represent the affected public at large.

Members of the public advisory council shall be appointed for terms of 3 years, except that, of the
			 members first appointed, 6 of the members shall be appointed for a term of
			 1 year and 6 of the members shall be appointed for a term of 2 years.

A member may be reappointed to serve on the public advisory council upon the expiration of the
			 member’s current term.

A vacancy on the public advisory council shall be filled in the same manner as the original
			 appointment.

A quorum shall be ten members of the public advisory council. The operations of the advisory
			 council shall not be impaired by the fact that a member has not yet been
			 appointed as long as a quorum has been attained.

The public advisory council shall elect a chairperson and establish such rules and procedures as it
			 deems necessary or desirable.
Members of the public advisory council shall serve without pay.
The public advisory council shall cease to exist—

on the date that is five years after the date on which the management plans are officially adopted
			 by the Secretaries; or
on such later date as the Secretaries consider appropriate.

header.#text: San Gabriel National Recreation Area Partnership

text.#text: There is hereby established the San Gabriel National Recreation Area Partnership.
The purposes of the partnership are to—

coordinate the activities of Federal, State, tribal, and local authorities, and the private sector,
			 in fulfilling the purposes of this Act; and

use the resources and expertise of each agency in improving the management and recreational
			 opportunities within the recreation area.
The members of the partnership shall include the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , or a designee of the Secretary, to represent the

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and

text.#text: The Secretary, or a designee of the Secretary, to represent the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , or a designee of the Secretary, to represent the

text.#text: The

The Secretary of the State Natural Resources Agency, or a designee of the Secretary, to represent
			 the California Department of Parks and Recreation and the Rivers and
			 Mountains Conservancy.
A designee of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors.
A designee of the San Bernardino County Board of Supervisors.
A designee of the Puente Hills Habitat Preservation Authority.

Four designees of the San Gabriel Council of Governments, one of whom is to be elected from a local
			 land conservancy.
Two designees of the San Bernardino Associated Governments.
A designee of the San Gabriel Valley Economic Partnership.
A designee of the Los Angeles County Flood Control District.
A designee of the San Gabriel Valley Water Association.
A designee of the Central Basin Water Association.
A designee of the Six Basins Watermaster.
A designee of a public utility company, to be appointed by the Secretary.
A designee of the Watershed Conservation Authority.
A designee of the public advisory council so long as the public advisory council remains in effect.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the partnership shall—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: San Gabriel National Recreation Area Act/s:3/ss:a

text.#text: To further the purposes of this Act, and in a manner consistent with the purposes described in

make recommendations to the Secretaries on the development and implementation of the management
			 plan;
advise the
review and comment on the visitor services plan and access study required by section 103;

seek opportunities to facilitate the implementation of the visitor services plan and access study
			 required by section 9;

assist units of local government, regional planning organizations, and nonprofit organizations in
			 fulfilling the purposes of the recreation area by—

carrying out programs and projects that recognize, protect, and enhance important resource values
			 within the recreation area;
establishing and maintaining interpretive exhibits and programs within the recreation area;

developing recreational and educational opportunities in the recreation area, consistent with the
			 purposes of this Act;

increasing public awareness of, and appreciation for, natural, historic, scenic, and cultural
			 resources of the recreation area;

ensuring that signs identifying points of public access and sites of interest are posted throughout
			 the recreation area;

promoting a wide range of partnerships among governments, organizations, and individuals to further
			 the purposes of the recreation area; and

ensuring that management of the recreation area takes into account local ordinances and land-use
			 plans, as well as adjacent residents and property owners;
make recommendations to the Secretaries on members to be appointed to the advisory council; and
undertake any other action necessary to fulfill the purposes of this Act.

The partnership may, subject to the prior approval of the Secretary, for the purposes of preparing
			 and implementing the management plans, use Federal funds made available
			 under this section to—

make grants to the State, political subdivisions of the State, nonprofit organizations, and other
			 persons;
hire and compensate staff;

obtain funds or services from any source, including funds and services provided under any other
			 Federal law or program;
contract for goods or services; and

support activities of partners and any other activities that further the purposes of the recreation
			 area and are consistent with the approved management plans.
Members of the partnership shall be appointed for terms of 3 years.

A member may be reappointed to serve on the partnership upon the expiration of the member’s current
			 term.
A vacancy on the partnership shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment.

A quorum shall be eleven members of the partnership. The operations of the partnership shall not be
			 impaired by the fact that a member has not yet been appointed as long as a
			 quorum has been attained.

The partnership shall elect a chairperson and establish such rules and procedures as it deems
			 necessary or desirable.
Members of the partnership shall serve without pay.

header.#text: Duties and authorities of the secretary

text.#text: The Secretary shall convene the partnership on a regular basis to carry out this Act.

text.#text: The Secretary is authorized to carry out the visitor services plan required by

The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance, on a reimbursable or non-reimbursable
			 basis, as determined by the Secretary, to the partnership or any members
			 of the partnership to carry out this Act.

The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with the partnership, any members of the
			 partnership, or other public or private entities to provide technical,
			 financial or other assistance to carry out this Act.

In order to facilitate the administration of the recreation area, the Secretary is authorized,
			 subject to valid existing rights, to construct administrative or visitor
			 use facilities on non-Federal public lands within the recreation area.
with the consent of the owner of the non-Federal public land; and
in accordance with applicable Federal, State, and local laws, regulations, and plans.
Such facilities may only be developed—

header.#text: Construction of facilities on non-Federal lands

text.#text: The Secretary shall give priority to actions that—

conserve the significant natural, historic, cultural, and scenic resources of the recreation area;
			 and

provide educational, interpretive, and recreational opportunities consistent with the purposes of
			 the recreation area.

text.#text: a

The purpose of this subsection is to facilitate the development of an integrated visitor services
			 plan that will improve visitor experiences within the recreation area
			 through expanded recreational opportunities, and increased interpretation,
			 education, resource protection, and enforcement.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and the Partnership, shall develop an integrated visitor
			 services plan for the recreation area.

text.#text:
Not later than three years after the date of the enactment of this Act, and in accordance with this
			 subsection, the Secretary, in consultation with the
The visitor services plan required by this subsection shall—

assess current and anticipated future visitation to the recreation area, including recreation
			 destinations;

evaluate the impacts of recreation on natural and cultural resources, water resource facilities,
			 public roads, adjacent residents and property owners, and utilities within
			 the recreation area, as well as the effectiveness of current enforcement
			 efforts;
assess the current level of interpretive and educational services and facilities;
include recommendations to—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: San Gabriel National Recreation Area Act/s:3/ss:a

text.#text:
expand opportunities for high-demand recreational activities, consistent with the purposes
			 described in

better manage recreation area resources and improve the experience of recreation area visitors
			 through expanded interpretive and educational services and facilities, and
			 improved enforcement; and

better manage recreation area resources to reduce negative impacts on the environment, ecology, and
			 integrated water management activities in the area;

in coordination and consultation with owners of non-Federal land, assess options to incorporate
			 recreational opportunities on non-Federal land into the recreation area—
in a manner consistent with the purposes and uses of the non-Federal land; and
with the consent of the non-Federal land owner;

assess opportunities to provide recreational opportunities that connect the San Gabriel River to
			 the National Forest System lands; and

be developed and carried out in accordance with applicable Federal, State, and local laws and
			 ordinances.
In developing the plan required by this subsection, the Secretary shall—
consult with—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and other appropriate Federal agencies;

text.#text: The Secretary and

The purpose of this subsection is to assess the feasibility of improving the accessibility of the
			 recreation area.

Not later than three years after the date of the enactment of this Act, and in accordance with this
			 subsection, the Secretary shall conduct a study on the accessibility of
			 the recreation area.
The access study required by this subsection shall—

evaluate the means by which members of the public access various locations within the recreation
			 area;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: from the San Gabriel River;

text.#text:
The Secretary may share resources such as management, research, planning, interpretation, visitor
			 services, and enforcement with any unit of the

The Secretary may share resources such as management, research, planning, interpretation, visitor
			 services, and enforcement with the Angeles National Forest in order to
			 fulfill the purposes of the recreation area.

The Secretary may provide technical assistance to interested public agencies, private landowners,
			 and organizations, to carry out the purposes of this Act.

Nothing in this Act shall authorize or require the use of water in or the diversion of water to the
			 recreation area or the park lands.
